attributes.title: Perceptual Processing of Novel Stimuli: An Effect of Working Memory versus Language
attributes.description: We report a partial replication of Lupyan & Spivel (2008) and Klemfuss, Prinzmetal, & Ivry (2012).

q1.value: Perceptual Processing of Novel Stimuli: An Effect of Working Memory versus Language

q2.value: Yijing Chen, Xinyue Hu, Eden Forbes, Davon Dowie, Joshua de Leeuw, Jan Andrews

q4.value:
H0: Nothing will happen

H1: When there is not a visual cue, the linguistic label will improve performance compared to no label. 

H2: When there is a visual cue, there will be no performance difference between conditions with linguistic labels and no linguistic labels. 

H3: The condition with cue and no linguistic label will have better performance compared to the condition with no cue and no linguistic label.

H4: There will be performance differences between the conditions with cue and no linguistic label and conditions with no cue and linguistic label.

H5: The condition with both linguistic label and visual cue will have better performance compared to the condition with linguistic label only

H6: The condition with both linguistic label and visual cue will have better performance compared to the condition with no linguistic label and no cue.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The participants are randomly assigned to language or abstract conditions, and the order of the cue blocks will be randomized. There are a total of 104 test trials and 6 practice trials. In all conditions, the oddball stimulus will be included at a random position in the array half of the time at random intervals. In each trial, participants will identify whether the display contains a homogenous set or an oddball. Each trial starts with the onset of the fixation cross or the visual cue depending on condition. The search array will be added to the display after a 1000-ms delay. Participants would respond by pressing one of the two keys to indicate if the display contains an item that is different than the other displayed items. Between each trial, there would be a 300-ms blank interval. Upon conclusion of the test, participants in the abstract condition will be asked whether or not they used any alpha-numeric symbols to help them identify the oddball. Finally, a debrief message is provided along with the participants’ average response times and accuracy.

The study will be distributed online to participants. The participant will first see a welcome screen displaying the following:
“Welcome to the experiment. Press any key to get started.”

Upon pressing a key, the participant will then receive the following instructions:
“In this experiment, you will see a set of 10 symbols arranged in a circle. Sometimes all of the symbols will match. Other times one of the symbols will be different than the others. Press the A key when one symbol is different. Press the L key when all symbols are the same. Press any key to continue.”

The participants will then be shown two sample displays using different symbols along with the appropriate keys to press:
“One of the symbols is different. Press the A key.”

“All of the symbols are the same. Press the L key.”

For the language group only, there will be an additional screen with example symbols that reads:
“These are the symbols that will be used in the experiment. Throughout the experiment you should think of these two symbols as rotated 2 and 5. Press 2 or 5 to continue.”

Then, one of two further instructions will be presented depending on which block of trials the subject begins with. If the cue condition (in which the oddball cue in the center of the symbols) is first, the screen will read:
“In this set of trials, the mismatching symbol will be presented to you in the center of the screen. You can use it as a reference to find the target. Please focus your gaze in the center until the symbol set is presented. Press any key to continue.” 

If the non-cue condition (fixation cross in the center of the symbols) is first, the screen will read: 
“In this set of trials, a fixation cross will be presented to you in the center of the screen. Please focus your gaze in the center until the symbol set is presented. Press any key to continue.”

Before the practice trials, the screen will read:
“Now you will complete three trials for practice. Press the A key if one of the symbols does not match and the L key if they all match. Press any key when you are ready to begin.”

Upon completion of the practice trials, the screen will display the following in all conditions:
“Now you will proceed to the test trials. Press the A key if one of the symbols does not match and the L key if they all match. Press any key when you are ready to begin.”

In the middle of the block, the symbols will switch such that the oddball in the previous half becomes the normal in the second half, and the normal in the previous half becomes the oddball in the second half. There will be instructions after the first half ended:
“Now the symbols will switch, where the target symbol will now be the nontarget and vice versa. The rest of the procedure will remain the same for the next chunk of trials, please continue to  press the A key if an oddball is present and the L key if no oddball is present. Press any key when you are ready to continue.”

When one block is completed, the subject will receive instructions for the other block. After the two blocks are finished, the participants will be asked a question.

For the abstract condition, the participants will be asked the following question:
“The stimuli used in this experiment could have been conceptualized as alpha-numeric symbols such as rotated 2s and 5s or Us and Ns. In your trials, did you use any alpha-numeric symbols such as these to help you identify the oddball symbols? Press the key A for Yes. Press the key L for No.”

For the language condition, the participants will be asked the following question:
“During the experiment, did you follow the initial instructions to think of the symbols as rotated 2s and 5s? Press the key A for Yes. Press the key L for No.”

Then for all participants, the debrief message will be displayed.
“You responded correctly on ____% of the trials. Your average response time was ____ms. Thank you for participating in our study. The purpose of this experiment was to see if the ability to detect the mismatched symbol was improved when it was shown in the center and/or when participants were instructed to think of the symbols as 2's and 5's turned on their side. These manipulations could be expected to reduce the burden on short-term memory. Thank you for participating!”

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to either the linguistic condition or the abstract condition. The order of the two blocks (cue and non-cue) and which of the two symbols is the oddball will be randomized. Which symbol is used as the oddball will be counterbalanced. The oddball would be presented in 50% of the trials, positioned on one of the ten positions with equal frequency.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The experiment will be programmed in jsPsych and distributed online through Prolific. The resulting data will be automatically collected by that program. The participants will be limited to fluent English speakers.

q13.value: We plan to collect 50 participants each for the linguistic and abstract conditions, totaling to 100 participants.

q14.value: We expect the experiment to take approximately 8 minutes. Based on our budget, we can afford to run around 100 subjects which will be split evenly between the two linguistic label conditions.

q15.value: The experiment will no longer be available when we have reached our maximum budget.

question.value:
Whether or not the linguistic cue is suggested (Linguistic/Non-Linguistic)
Whether or not the display includes the oddball cue (Presence/Absence of Cue)

Reaction Time (ms)
Whether or not the subject correctly identifies if there is an oddball (Correct/Incorrect)
Whether or not subjects in the control group used linguistic symbols on their own (Y/N)

A two-way ANOVA on reaction time with Task Description (Linguistic/Non-Linguistic) as a between-subjects factor and Task Set (Cue/Non-Cue) as a within-subjects factor. Only trials in which the subject answered correctly will be included for analysis. Then, we would do another two-way ANOVA with the same factors but excluding the subjects in the abstract condition who used alpha-numeric symbols on their own.

q21.value: For our statistical model as well as our exploratory analysis, we will be using the traditional ⍺ = 0.05 overall and for each ANOVA analysis we would use ⍺ = 0.025.

q22.value: We will exclude incorrect responses and responses with a reaction time greater than a certain threshold. This threshold will be defined based upon a histogram of all reaction times from the results independent of the various conditions.

q24.value: Within the abstract (no language) group, we will run a t-test to determine if those who used linguistic symbols on their own had better performance as in Lupyan (2008).

attributes.title: April 2020 Study
attributes.description: In this study we explore the effect of sharing negative evaluative information about a third party on the friendship between two same-sex people.

copyright_holders: Laureon A. Merrie and Jaimie Arona Krems

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: April 2020 Study: first- vs. third-person perceptions of those who share negative evaluative information

other.value: We will also be exploring how much the receiver of the information likes the sharer, and whether participants perceive that the receiver would like the sharer more than the subject of the information. Because participants are responding to sex-matched stimuli, we will also explore gender differences to some extent.

sample.value: Based on the effect size from our previous study (f = .13), a power analysis was conducted using G*Power. A total of 456 participants will be needed in our sample.

analyses.value: A series of factorial ANOVAs will be conducted to test each of these questions.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from analyses if they appear to be likely bots or fail either or both of our attention checks throughout the survey.

Our bot/attention check questions include asking participants to list the name of a same-sex best friend, a same-sex close friend, and an opposite-sex acquaintance. Those who list the same name in all three boxes, who list names that are apparently not of the correct sex, write non-names in the boxes, or leave one or more of the boxes blank will be excluded as likely bots. 

Our second bot/attention check question asks participants to type the word "thoughts" into a textbox. Those who either select a multiple choice option labeled "thoughts" or type words other than "thoughts" into the box will be excluded. 

Finally, our last bot/attention check question asks participants to type the word "ethnicity" into a text box option rather than selecting one of several other options. Those who do not type the word "ethnicity" will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value:
Trust will be assessed using eight face-valid items (e.g., "I would trust Abby/Aaron") responded to on a six-point Likert-type scale (1 = "Definitely not," 6 = "Definitely so").

Perceptions of the information sharer will be assessed using items taken from the trustworthiness subscale of the Witness Credibility Scale (Brodsky et al., 2010). Participants will rate Abby/Aaron on each of eight characteristics (e.g., "Reliable") using eight-point bipolar scales. 

Liking the receiver will be assessed by a single item asking participants to rate how much they think Abby/Aaron likes the person they shared the information with, using a slider (0 = "Not at all," 100 = "Very much").

Liking the receiver more than the subject of the information will be assessed with a single item asking the likelihood that Abby/Aaron likes the person they shared the information with more than the person the information was about. Participants will respond using a slider (0 = "Extremely unlikely," 100 = "Extremely Likely").

conditions.value:
There will be four conditions. Participants will be randomly assigned to read about the situation from either a first-person perspective (where they are asked to imagine themselves in the situation) or from a third-person perspective (where they read about other people in the situation). They will also be randomly assigned to read a version of the situation where a friend shares either negative or neutral evaluative information about a mutual friend.

The design is a between-subjects 2(story perspective: first- vs. third-person) X 2(information shared: negative evaluative vs. neutral evaluative).

hypothesis.value:
- Are people more favorable toward targets who share negative evaluative information about others when those targets share information with them (first person) versus when they observe the target sharing this information with another (third-person). We predict that people will rate targets more favorably when those targets share negative evaluative information about others (versus do not), in the first- versus third-person condition. 

- We also predict that people will perceive targets as more favorable toward them when those targets share negative evaluative information about others (versus do not)---especially in the first- versus third-person condition. 

We hypothesize that a friend will be trusted more and perceived more positively by participants when participants read about that friend sharing negative evaluative information about someone else from a first-person perspective than from a third-person perspective. 

We hypothesize that a friend who shares negative evaluative information about a third party will be perceived as liking the receiver of that information more by participants who read about this situation from a first-person perspective than those who read about it from a third-person perspective.

We also hypothesize that when a person shares negative evaluative information about a third party with a friend, the receiver of the information will be perceived as being liked by the sharer more than the subject of the information more so by participants who read about this situation from a first-person perspective than those reading about it from a third-person perspective.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

Because participants are responding to sex-matched stimuli, we will also explore gender differences to some extent.

Our second bot/attention check question asks participants to type the word "thoughts" into a textbox. Those who either select a multiple choice option labeled "thoughts" or type words other than "thoughts" into the box will be excluded.

The design is a between-subjects 2(story perspective: first- vs. third-person) X 2(information shared: negative evaluative vs. neutral evaluative).

We predict that people will rate targets more favorably when those targets share negative evaluative information about others (versus do not), in the first- versus third-person condition. 

- We also predict that people will perceive targets as more favorable toward them when those targets share negative evaluative information about others (versus do not)---especially in the first- versus third-person condition.

attributes.title: A systematic review of the burden of stroke in Ghana.
attributes.description: A comprehensive systematic review to collect current evidence on the burden of stroke in Ghana.

summary.value: This is a systematic review which will analyze both qualitative and quantitative data from current literature on the burden of stroke in Ghana.

registration_responses.summary: This is a systematic review which will analyze both qualitative and quantitative data from current literature on the burden of stroke in Ghana.

attributes.title: Personal social networks, loneliness and well-being during the COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description: A 12 week longitudinal study of egocentric social network characteristics, loneliness and well-being during the COVIS-19 pandemic.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Personal social networks, loneliness and well-being in older adults during the COVID-19 Pandemic: A 12-week longitudinal survey.

other.value: Thirty-three observations had been recorded at the time of pre-registration. This was an oversight whilst adapting to alternative working arrangements and developing a new study rapidly during the pandemic. Ethical approval was granted by our local ethics committee prior to data collection. The ethics documents uploaded on the project page can confirm that no changes have been made since that time.

sample.value: We aim to collect a minimum of 100 observations. This number is due to the likely difficulty recruiting during the pandemic while being sufficient to run the appropriate analyses.

analyses.value:
Correlation, regression and growth curve modelling will be used to determine which social network aspects are most beneficial in terms of improving loneliness and well-being.

 Comparisons between the groups will be assessed via regression discontinuity analysis.

outliers.value: Incomplete data will be removed prior to analysis. Extreme outliers will be winsorized to 3SD above and below the mean.

dependent.value:
The UCLA Loneliness Scale Version 3 - Russell, D. (1996). UCLA Loneliness Scale (Version 3): Reliability, validity, and factor structure. Journal of Personality Assessment, 66, 20-40.

The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale ‐ Zigmond, A. S., & Snaith, R. P. (1983). The hospital anxiety and depression scale. Acta psychiatrica scandinavica, 67(6), 361‐370.

Warick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale ‐ Tennant, R., Hiller, L., Fishwick, R., Platt, S., Joseph, S., Weich, S., ... & Stewart‐Brown, S. (2007). The WarwickEdinburgh mental well‐being scale (WEMWBS): development and UK validation. Health and Quality of life Outcomes, 5(1), 63.

hypothesis.value:
How does contact from an individual's social network impact on loneliness and well-being during the COVID-19 pandemic, specifically which:

Relationship Type (family/non-family/specific relationship)
Relationship Length
Contact Type
Contact Frequency
Emotional Closeness
Network Size and Density

are most optimal in terms of loneliness and wellbeing in older adults during this pandemic?

How do these effects differ between those self-isolating and those not self-isolating?

summary.value: Please see the attached PDF (humor_framing_prereg_addendum.pdf) for the preregistration.

registration_responses.summary: Please see the attached PDF (humor_framing_prereg_addendum.pdf) for the preregistration.

attributes.title: Framing effects on the effectiveness and virality of health messages related to COVID-19
attributes.description: This is an addendum to the preregistration about the effects of humorous framing of COVID-19 health messaging on intentions and attitudes about social distancing. In this addendum, we explore the effect of mocking humorous framing in contrast to non-mocking humorous framing and factual framing on 1) self/social relevance of COVID-19 health messages, and 2) dehumanization of vulnerable groups.

summary.value: Please see the attached PDF (humor_framing_prereg_addendum.pdf) for the preregistration.

registration_responses.summary: Please see the attached PDF (humor_framing_prereg_addendum.pdf) for the preregistration.
